name: Contiguous box plots
description:
Contiguous visualization combines several distribution visualization by placing them next to each other. The x-axis represents the time dimension, where each distribution is a unit of time.
A box plot is a visual representation of a distribution, displaying key statistics like median, quartiles, and potential outliers. A rectangular box spans the interquartile range (IQR) with a line denoting the median. Whiskers extend to show the range within 1.5 times the IQR, and individual points beyond are marked as outliers.

name: Contiguous md plots
description:
Contiguous visualization combines several distribution visualization by placing them next to each other. The x-axis represents the time dimension, where each distribution is a unit of time.
A mirror density plot is a plot of the estimated kernel density of a distribution. The mirror curves represent the density of the data, with wider sections indicating higher data density.

name: Contiguous violin plots
description:
Contiguous visualization combines several distribution visualization by placing them next to each other. The x-axis represents the time dimension, where each distribution is a unit of time.
A violin plot is a graphical representation of a distribution, combining aspects of a box plot and a kernel density plot. It features a symmetrical shape resembling a violin, with wider sections indicating higher data density. The plot displays quartiles (as a rectangle) and median (as a point inside quartiles’ rectangle) like a box plot but provides a more detailed view of the data's probability density.

name: Contiguous bean plots
description:
Contiguous visualization combines several distribution visualization by placing them next to each other. The x-axis represents the time dimension, where each distribution is a unit of time.
A bean plot is a graphical representation of a distribution, combining aspects of a scatter plot and a kernel density plot. It features a symmetrical shape resembling a bean, with wider sections indicating higher data density. The plot displays individuals as beans (lines) and provides a more detailed view of the data's probability density.

name: Ridgeline plots
description: Contiguous visualization combines several distribution visualizations by placing them above each other with a slight overlap. The y-axis represents the time dimension where each distribution is a unit of time.

name: Contiguous discrete heatmap plot
description: A heat map is a visual representation of the distribution where color is used to represent the distribution density. In this visualization, the x-axis represents the time dimension (each column being a discrete distribution) and the y-axis models the working feature.

name: Continuous colormap plus
description: A color map plus is a visual representation of the distribution where color is used to represent the distribution density. In this visualization, the x-axis represents the time dimension (each column being a contiguous distribution) and the y-axis models the working feature. The add-on of this visualization is the overlay of statistical descriptors (Min, Max, Q1, median, Q2) in the form of a line chart.

name: Overlapping box plots
description:
Overlapping display methods use time to display the distribution one by one. It is done by placing successively distributions upon each other resulting in a video-like visualization (gif).
A box plot is a visual representation of a distribution, displaying key statistics like median, quartiles, and potential outliers. A rectangular box spans the interquartile range (IQR) with a line denoting the median. Whiskers extend to show the range within 1.5 times the IQR, and individual points beyond are marked as outliers.

name: Overlapping mirror density plots
description:
Overlapping display methods use time to display the distribution one by one. It is done by placing successively distributions upon each other resulting in a video-like visualization (gif).
A mirror density plot is a plot of the estimated kernel density of a distribution. The mirror curves represent the density of the data, with wider sections indicating higher data density.

name: Overlapping violin plots
description:
Overlapping display methods use time to display the distribution one by one. It is done by placing successively distributions upon each other resulting in a video-like visualization (gif).
A violin plot is a graphical representation of a distribution, combining aspects of a box plot and a kernel density plot. It features a symmetrical shape resembling a violin, with wider sections indicating higher data density. The plot displays quartiles (as a rectangle) and median (as a point inside quartiles’ rectangle) like a box plot but provides a more detailed view of the data's probability density.

name: Overlapping bean plots
description:
Overlapping display methods use time to display the distribution one by one. It is done by placing successively distributions upon each other resulting in a video-like visualization (gif).
A bean plot is a graphical representation of a distribution, combining aspects of a scatter plot and a kernel density plot. It features a symmetrical shape resembling a bean, with wider sections indicating higher data density. The plot displays individuals as beans (lines) and provides a more detailed view of the data's probability density.

name: Radial edge bundling
description: Graphical visualization where each node is a distribution and each vertex is represented if two distributions are similar (the more similar two distributions are, the thicker the edge).

name: Arc diagram plus
description:
Graphical visualization where each node is a distribution and each vertex is represented if two distributions are similar (the more similar two distributions are, the thicker the edge).
It is combined with a contiguous_box_plots.
